Question: Can the Cyclone Rake connect to a Ventrac mower?
Answer:
While it is theoretically possible to connect the Cyclone Rake to a Ventrac mower, we strongly advise against it. We can connect the hitch, MDA, and deck hose to the mower, but you will not be able to make a left-hand turn and turning right will be difficult. A hanger bracket will need to be manufactured and the overall length makes it cumbersome. Based on customer feedback, we do not recommend connecting to this mower. (One of our customers needed 14 feet of hose to use the Cyclone Rake).

You could use a longer hose, but you would have to pay extra for additional hose, and it undercuts the fundamental design of the Cyclone Rake. Not only does the dual pin hitch allow a rigid mount, and makes it impossible to jackknife, it also allows us to use the shortest, and straightest length of deck hose possible. The dual pin hitch allows us to use a fixed length of hose, all but eliminating the opportunity for the clogging and hassle you see in other machines with long, winding hoses. Having the mower articulate would defeat the purpose of our design.

Plan your mowing path to minimize time spent on hills

Start with a full tank

For steep yards, work downhill first, while the tank is fullest

Question: Can I use my Cyclone Rake in the rain?
Answer:
We would not recommend using your Cyclone Rake in the rain, or leaving it exposed to any kind of precipitation. There are electrical connections maintaining the spark within your Cyclone Rake engine, as it is an internal combustion engine. Water can affect those connections negatively. Additionally, water entering the inside of the engine can damage parts when running.

All that is to say - it's not ideal to run the engine in the rain, or to leave the engine uncovered if stored outside. Keep your Cyclone Rake in a dry sheltered place. Be sure to get out any organic debris from the bag before putting it away for storage. Acorns, nuts, and other debris will attract mice and rodents. Mothballs will help keep them away!

Lastly, always add fuel stabilizer to keep the fuel fresh. There is no need to drain gasoline from the engine if a fuel stabilizer is added. Fuel can become stale when stored for over 30 days. Adding fuel stabilizer will prevent gum and varnish buildup. Keep the gas tank 95% full to avoid condensation buildup in the tank during storage. Run the engine for 5 minutes after adding the stabilizer to treat the entire fuel system. This prepares the engine and gasoline for up to 24 months of storage. While not specifically required for daily use, Briggs & Stratton does recommend the use of fuel treatment and stabilizer as a regular part of the refueling process.

Question: Can I buy the liner separate and install it myself?
Answer:
Among the parts we sell, the blower housing liner is the only one not sold separately and we want to share with you why.

With 25 years of experience selling and supporting Cyclone Rakes, we have a deep understanding of its operation and how parts wear.

As materials move through the blower housing, the liner protects the inside of the housing from the abrasive conditions. If the liner wears through, it exposes the housing to the abrasion, resulting in a failure. Furthermore, we have found that when the liner fails, the housing can also experience excessive wear.

The reason for not selling it separately is that an improperly installed liner could cause other problems and pose safety concerns. A properly seated liner is critical since the impeller must never come in contact with the liner. If this occurs, it can create chips in the impeller and lead to an “out-of-round situation”, which can damage both the impeller and the engine. As you can understand, a liner that has not been installed properly and comes loose during operation is also a safety hazard that we take very seriously.

We understand many of our customers are handy around the shop and take very good care of their tools. We're not here to tell you how to maintain your property and respect your decision to use and repair your tools as you see fit. However, we also want you to understand why we made this decision and why it is in place today.

Question: Why Are My Wheels Shaking So Much!?
Answer:
It's not uncommon to notice some wheel shaking or wobbling when using your Cyclone Rake. While a certain amount of movement is actually by design, excessive shaking can be addressed with a few simple adjustments.

Our engineers purposely designed the Cyclone Rake wheels with some flexibility to help navigate bumpy terrain. If you're experiencing more wheel movement than seems normal, consider these common factors:

1. Operating Speed

Wheels tend to shake more at higher speeds, especially on hard surfaces like pavement or concrete
Try reducing your speed to see if this reduces the shaking
Remember that the Cyclone Rake is designed primarily for use on lawn surfaces, not for high-speed transportation

2. Load Distribution

An empty collector can lead to more noticeable wobbling
As the collector fills, the added weight often stabilizes the wheels
This is why the shaking might decrease as you collect more debris

3. Surface Type

Hard, flat surfaces like driveways or pavement tend to amplify wheel movement
Softer surfaces like grass and soil naturally dampen vibrations
The wheels will typically shake less on the turf areas where you'll be doing most of your work

Quick Fixes for Wheel Shaking

Adjust Tire Pressure
One of the most effective solutions is ensuring proper tire inflation:
Dual-PRO Super Wheels: Maintain 12-15 PSI per tire
Single Wheels: Maintain 20-25 PSI per tire
Use slower speeds when operating on hard surfaces
Take turns more gradually
Avoid rapid acceleration and deceleration

Incorrect tire pressure is frequently the cause of excessive wheel shaking. Check your pressure and adjust accordingly.

Question: Can I store my Cyclone Rake dry?
Answer:

While it may seem convenient, we don’t recommend storing your Cyclone Rake engine dry for long periods. Here’s why:

Why You Shouldn’t Store It Dry:
Even though we ship the engine without fluids, small amounts of oil and fuel residue are left behind from factory testing

Over time, these residues can dry out and cause internal issues, like stuck valves or gummed-up fuel components

If You Do Choose to Store It Dry:
Plan to take it out of storage in early spring (around March)

Add fresh oil, gas, and fuel stabilizer

Run the engine for about 30 minutes to circulate fluids and keep internal parts in good shape

After that, you can let it cool and store it again until fall if needed

This helps prevent startup issues and keeps your engine healthy during the off-season.

Here's why:
Mulching kits block the mower’s discharge chute, which is exactly where the Cyclone Rake connects

The Cyclone Rake requires a completely open discharge chute to generate proper airflow and suction

The mulching cover or plug physically interferes with the Mower Deck Adapter (MDA) or rubber collar connection

What You’ll Need to Do:
To use the Cyclone Rake:

Remove the mulching kit

Ensure the chute is clear

Attach the MDA and hose as instructed

To mulch again:

Disconnect the Cyclone Rake

Reinstall the mulching kit
